text: ਸਲੋਕ ਸੇਖ ਫਰੀਦ ਕੇ
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Shaloks Of Shaykh Fareed Jee:

transliteration.text: salōk sēkh pharīd kē

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ੴ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

transliteration.text: ik ōunkār satigur prasād .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਜਿਤੁ ਦਿਹਾੜੈ ਧਨ ਵਰੀ ਸਾਹੇ ਲਏ ਲਿਖਾਇ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The day of the bride's wedding is pre-ordained.

transliteration.text: jit dihārai dhan varī sāhē laē likhāi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਮਲਕੁ ਜਿ ਕੰਨੀ ਸੁਣੀਦਾ ਮੁਹੁ ਦੇਖਾਲੇ ਆਇ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: On that day, the Messenger of Death, of whom she had only heard, comes and shows its face.

transliteration.text: malak j kannī sunīdā muh dēkhālē āi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: It breaks the bones of the body and pulls the helpless soul out.

transliteration.text: jind nimānī kadhīai hadā kū karakāi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: That pre-ordained time of marriage cannot be avoided. Explain this to your soul.

transliteration.text: sāhē likhē n chalanī jindū kūn samajhāi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The soul is the bride, and death is the groom. He will marry her and take her away.

transliteration.text: jind vahutī maran var lai jāsī paranāi .

translation.text: After the body sends her away with its own hands, whose neck will it embrace?

transliteration.text: āpan hathī jōl kai kai gal lagai dhāi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The bridge to hell is narrower than a hair; haven't you heard of it with your ears?

transliteration.text: vālah nikī purasalāt kannī n sunī āi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the call has come; be careful now - don't let yourself be robbed. ||1||

transliteration.text: pharīdā kirī pavandīī kharā n āp muhāi .1.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, it is so difficult to become a humble Saint at the Lord's Door.

transliteration.text: pharīdā dar daravēsī gākharī chalānh dunīānh bhat .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: I am so accustomed to walking in the ways of the world. I have tied and picked up the bundle; where can I go to throw it away? ||2||

transliteration.text: bannh uthāī pōtalī kithai vanñā ghat .2.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: I know nothing; I understand nothing. The world is a smouldering fire.

transliteration.text: kijh n bujhai kijh n sujhai dunīā gujhī bhāh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: My Lord did well to warn me about it; otherwise, I would have been burnt as well. ||3||

transliteration.text: sānhīnh mērai changā kītā nāhī t han bhī dajhānh āh .3.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, if I had known that I had so few sesame seeds, I would have been more careful with them in my hands.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jē jānā til thōrarē sanmal buk bharī .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: If I had known that my Husband Lord was so young and innocent, I would not have been so arrogant. ||4||

translation.text: If I had known that my robe would come loose, I would have tied a tighter knot.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: I have found none as great as You, Lord; I have looked and searched throughout the world. ||5||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, if you have a keen understanding, then do not write black marks against anyone else.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jē tū akal latīph kālē likh n lēkh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Look underneath your own collar instead. ||6||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, do not turn around and strike those who strike you with their fists.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jō tai māran mukīānh tinhā n mārē ghunm .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Kiss their feet, and return to your own home. ||7||

transliteration.text: āpanarai ghar jāīai pair tinhā dē chunm .7.

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਫਰੀਦਾ ਜਾਂ ਤਉ ਖਟਣ ਵੇਲ ਤਾਂ ਤੂ ਰਤਾ ਦੁਨੀ ਸਿਉ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, when there was time for you to earn good karma, you were in love with the world instead.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jānh tau khatan vēl tānh tū ratā dunī siu .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Now, death has a strong foothold; when the load is full, it is taken away. ||8||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Without my Lord, who can I tell of my sorrow? ||10||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, my eyes have become weak, and my ears have become hard of hearing.

translation.text: The body's crop has become ripe and turned color. ||11||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, those who did not enjoy their Spouse when their hair was black - hardly any of them enjoy Him when their hair turns grey.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: Fareed, whether one's hair is black or grey, our Lord and Master is always here if one remembers Him.

transliteration.text: pharīdā kālī dhaulī sāhib sadā hai jē kō chit karē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਆਪਣਾ ਲਾਇਆ ਪਿਰਮੁ ਨ ਲਗਈ ਜੇ ਲੋਚੈ ਸਭੁ ਕੋਇ ॥
section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: This loving devotion to the Lord does not come by one's own efforts, even though all may long for it.

transliteration.text: āpanā lāiā piram n lagaī jē lōchai sabh kōi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: This cup of loving devotion belongs to our Lord and Master; He gives it to whomever He likes. ||13||

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, do not slander the dust; noting is as great as dust.

transliteration.text: pharīdā khāk n nindīai khākū jēd n kōi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: When we are alive, it is under our feet, and when we are dead, it is above us. ||17||

transliteration.text: jīvadiā pairā talai muiā upar hōi .17.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, when there is greed, what love can there be? When there is greed, love is false.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jā lab tā nēh kiā lab t kūrā nēh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: How long can one remain in a thatched hut which leaks when it rains? ||18||

transliteration.text: kichar jhat laghāīai shapar tutai mēh .18.

translation.text: Fareed, why do you wander from jungle to jungle, crashing through the thorny trees?

transliteration.text: pharīdā jangal jangal kiā bhavah van kandā mōrēh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The Lord abides in the heart; why are you looking for Him in the jungle? ||19||

transliteration.text: vasī rab hiālīai jangal kiā dhūdhēh .19.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, with these small legs, I crossed deserts and mountains.

transliteration.text: pharīdā inī nikī janghīai thal dūngar bhaviōmh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: But today, Fareed, my water jug seems hundreds of miles away. ||20||

translation.text: Fareed, the nights are long, and my sides are aching in pain.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Cursed are the lives of those who place their hopes in others. ||21||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, if I had been there when my friend came, I would have made myself a sacrifice to him.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਫਰੀਦਾ ਸਕਰ ਖੰਡੁ ਨਿਵਾਤ ਗੁੜੁ ਮਾਖਿਓੁ ਮਾਂਝਾ ਦੁਧੁ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed: sugar cane, candy, sugar, molasses, honey and buffalo's milk

transliteration.text: pharīdā sakar khand nivāt gur mākhiō mānhjhā dudh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: - all these things are sweet, but they are not equal to You. ||27||

transliteration.text: sabhē vasatū mithīānh rab n pujan tudh .27.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, my bread is made of wood, and hunger is my appetizer.

transliteration.text: pharīdā rōtī mērī kāth kī lāvan mērī bhukh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Those who eat buttered bread, will suffer in terrible pain. ||28||

transliteration.text: jinā khādhī chōparī ghanē sahanigē dukh .28.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Eat dry bread, and drink cold water.

transliteration.text: rukhī sukhī khāi kai thandhā pānī pīu .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, if you see someone else's buttered bread, do not envy him for it. ||29||

transliteration.text: pharīdā dēkh parāī chōparī nā tarasāē jīu .29.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: This night, I did not sleep with my Husband Lord, and now my body is suffering in pain.

transliteration.text: aj n sutī kant siu ang murē mur jāi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Go and ask the deserted bride, how she passes her night. ||30||

transliteration.text: jāi pushah dōhāganī tum kiu rain vihāi .30.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: She finds no place of rest in her father-in-law's home, and no place in her parents' home either.

transliteration.text: sāhurai dhōī nā lahai pēīai nāhī thāu .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Her Husband Lord does not care for her; what sort of a blessed, happy soul-bride is she? ||31||

transliteration.text: pir vātarī n pushaī dhan sōhāgan nāu .31.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: In her father-in-law's home hereafter, and in her parents' home in this world, she belongs to her Husband Lord. Her Husband is Inaccessible and Unfathomable.

transliteration.text: sāhurai pēīai kant kī kant aganm athāh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: O Nanak, she is the happy soul-bride, who is pleasing to her Carefree Lord. ||32||

transliteration.text: nānak sō sōhāganī j bhāvai bēparavāh .32.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Bathing, washing and decorating herself, she comes and sleeps without anxiety.

transliteration.text: nātī dhōtī sanbahī sutī āi nachind .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, she still smells like asafoetida; the fragrance of musk is gone. ||33||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: I am not afraid of losing my youth, as long as I do not lose the Love of my Husband Lord.

transliteration.text: jōban jānhdē nā darānh jē sah prīt n jāi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, so many youths, without His Love, have dried up and withered away. ||34||

transliteration.text: pharīdā kitīnh jōban prīt bin suk gaē kumalāi .34.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, anxiety is my bed, pain is my mattress, and the pain of separation is my blanket and quilt.

transliteration.text: pharīdā chint khatōlā vān dukh birah vishāvan lēph .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Behold, this is my life, O my True Lord and Master. ||35||

transliteration.text: ēh hamārā jīvanā tū sāhib sachē vēkh .35.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Many talk of the pain and suffering of separation; O pain, you are the ruler of all.

transliteration.text: birahā birahā ākhīai birahā tū sulatān .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, that body, within which love of the Lord does not well up - look upon that body as a cremation ground. ||36||

transliteration.text: pharīdā jit tan birah n ūpajai sō tan jān masān .36.

author.description:

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਫਰੀਦਾ ਏ ਵਿਸੁ ਗੰਦਲਾ ਧਰੀਆਂ ਖੰਡੁ ਲਿਵਾੜਿ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, these are poisonous sprouts coated with sugar.

transliteration.text: pharīdā ē vis gandalā dharīānh khand livār .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Some die planting them, and some are ruined, harvesting and enjoying them. ||37||

transliteration.text: ik rāhēdē rah gaē ik rādhī gaē ujār .37.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the hours of the day are lost wandering around, and the hours of the night are lost in sleep.

transliteration.text: pharīdā chār gavāiā handh kai chār gavāiā sanm .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: God will call for your account, and ask you why you came into this world. ||38||

transliteration.text: lēkhā rab mangēsīā tū ānhhō kērhē kanm .38.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, you have gone to the Lord's Door. Have you seen the gong there?

transliteration.text: pharīdā dar daravājai jāi kai kiu dithō gharīāl .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: This blameless object is being beaten - imagine what is in store for us sinners! ||39||

transliteration.text: ēh nidōsānh mārīai ham dōsānh dā kiā hāl .39.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Each and every hour, it is beaten; it is punished every day.

transliteration.text: gharīē gharīē mārīai paharī lahai sajāi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: This beautiful body is like the gong; it passes the night in pain. ||40||

transliteration.text: sō hērā gharīāl jiu dukhī rain vihāi .40.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Shaykh Fareed has grown old, and his body has begun to tremble.

transliteration.text: budhā hōā sēkh pharīd kanban lagī dēh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Even if he could live for hundreds of years, his body will eventually turn to dust. ||41||

transliteration.text: jē sau varhiā jīvanā bhī tan hōsī khēh .41.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed begs, O Lord, do not make me sit at another's door.

transliteration.text: pharīdā bār parāiai baisanā sānhī mujhai n dēh .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: If this is the way you are going to keep me, then go ahead and take the life out of my body. ||42||

transliteration.text: jē tū ēvai rakhasī jīu sarīrah lēh .42.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: With the axe on his shoulder, and a bucket on his head, the blacksmith is ready to cut down the tree.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, I long for my Lord; you long only for the charcoal. ||43||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, some have lots of flour, while others do not even have salt.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: When they go beyond this world, it shall be seen, who will be punished. ||44||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Drums were beaten in their honor, there were canopies above their heads, and bugles announced their coming.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, those who built houses, mansions and lofty buildings, are also gone.

translation.text: They made false deals, and were dropped into their graves. ||46||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, you wear your prayer shawl on your shoulders and the robes of a Sufi; your words are sweet, but there is a dagger in your heart.

translation.text: Fareed, not even a drop of blood would issue forth, if someone cut my body.

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: This body is all blood; without blood, this body could not exist.

transliteration.text: ih tan sabhō rat hai rat bin tann n hōi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਜੋ ਸਹ ਰਤੇ ਆਪਣੇ ਤਿਤੁ ਤਨਿ ਲੋਭੁ ਰਤੁ ਨ ਹੋਇ ॥
section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: Those who are imbued with their Lord, do not have the blood of greed in their bodies.

transliteration.text: jō sah ratē āpanē tit tan lōbh rat n hōi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: When the Fear of God fills the body, it becomes thin; the blood of greed departs from within.

text: ਫਰੀਦਾ ਸਿਰੁ ਪਲਿਆ ਦਾੜੀ ਪਲੀ ਮੁਛਾਂ ਭੀ ਪਲੀਆਂ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, your hair has turned grey, your beard has turned grey, and your moustache has turned grey.

transliteration.text: pharīdā sir paliā dārī palī mushānh bhī palīānh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਰੇ ਮਨ ਗਹਿਲੇ ਬਾਵਲੇ ਮਾਣਹਿ ਕਿਆ ਰਲੀਆਂ ॥੫੫॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: O my thoughtless and insane mind, why are you indulging in pleasures? ||55||

transliteration.text: rē man gahilē bāvalē mānah kiā ralīānh .55.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, how long can you run on the rooftop? You are asleep to your Husband Lord - give it up!

transliteration.text: pharīdā kōthē dhukan kētarā pir nīdarī nivār .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The days which were allotted to you are numbered, and they are passing, passing away. ||56||

transliteration.text: jō dih ladhē gānavē gaē vilār vilār .56.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, houses, mansions and balconies - do not attach your consciousness to these.

transliteration.text: pharīdā kōthē mandap mārīā ēt n lāē chit .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: When these collapse into heaps of dust, none of them will be your friend. ||57||

transliteration.text: mitī paī atōlavī kōi n hōsī mit .57.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, do not focus on mansions and wealth; center your consciousness on death, your powerful enemy.

transliteration.text: pharīdā mandap māl n lāi marag satānī chit dhar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Remember that place where you must go. ||58||

transliteration.text: sāī jāi samhāl jithai hī tau vanñanā .58.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, those deeds which do not bring merit - forget about those deeds.

transliteration.text: pharīdā jinhī kanmī nāh gun tē kanmarē visār .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Otherwise, you shall be put to shame, in the Court of the Lord. ||59||

transliteration.text: mat saramindā thīvahī sānhī dai darabār .59.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, work for your Lord and Master; dispel the doubts of your heart.

transliteration.text: pharīdā sāhib dī kar chākarī dil dī lāh bharānhd .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The dervishes, the humble devotees, have the patient endurance of trees. ||60||

transliteration.text: daravēsānh nō lōrīai rukhānh dī jīrānhd .60.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, my clothes are black, and my outfit is black.

transliteration.text: pharīdā kālē maidē kaparē kālā maidā vēs .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: I wander around full of sins, and yet people call me a dervish - a holy man. ||61||

transliteration.text: gunahī bhariā mai phirā lōk kahai daravēs .61.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The crop which is burnt will not bloom, even if it is soaked in water.

transliteration.text: tatī tōi n palavai jē jal tubī dēi .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, she who is forsaken by her Husband Lord, grieves and laments. ||62||

transliteration.text: pharīdā jō dōhāgan rab dī jhūrēdī jhūrēi .62.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: When she is a virgin, she is full of desire; but when she is married, then her troubles begin.

transliteration.text: jānh kuārī tā chāu vīvāhī tānh māmalē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, she has this one regret, that she cannot be a virgin again. ||63||

transliteration.text: pharīdā ēhō pashōtāu vat kuārī n thīai .63.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The swans have landed in a small pond of salt water.

transliteration.text: kalar kērī shaparī āi ulathē hanjh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: They dip in their bills, but do not drink; they fly away, still thirsty. ||64||

transliteration.text: chinjū bōranh nā pīvah udan sandī danjh .64.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The swans fly away, and land in the fields of grain. The people go to chase them away.

transliteration.text: hans udar kōdhrai paiā lōk vidāran jāi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਗਹਿਲਾ ਲੋਕੁ ਨ ਜਾਣਦਾ ਹੰਸੁ ਨ ਕੋਧ੍ਰਾ ਖਾਇ ॥੬੫॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The thoughtless people do not know, that the swans do not eat the grain. ||65||

transliteration.text: gahilā lōk n jānadā hans n kōdhrā khāi .65.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The birds which lived in the pools have flown away and left.

transliteration.text: chal chal gaīānh pankhīānh jinhī vasāē tal .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the overflowing pool shall also pass away, and only the lotus flowers shall remain. ||66||

transliteration.text: pharīdā sar bhariā bhī chalasī thakē kaval ikal .66.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, a stone will be your pillow, and the earth will be your bed. The worms shall eat into your flesh.

transliteration.text: pharīdā it sirānē bhui savan kīrā lariō mās .

translation.text: Countless ages will pass, and you will still be lying on one side. ||67||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, your beautiful body shall break apart, and the subtle thread of the breath shall be snapped.

translation.text: In which house will the Messenger of Death be a guest today? ||68||

translation.text: Fareed: O faithless dog, this is not a good way of life.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: You never come to the mosque for your five daily prayers. ||70||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Rise up, Fareed, and cleanse yourself; chant your morning prayer.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the Creator is in the Creation, and the Creation abides in God.

transliteration.text: pharīdā khālak khalak mah khalak vasai rab māh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਮੰਦਾ ਕਿਸ ਨੋ ਆਖੀਐ ਜਾਂ ਤਿਸੁ ਬਿਨੁ ਕੋਈ ਨਾਹਿ ॥੭੫॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Whom can we call bad? There is none without Him. ||75||

translation.text: Fareed, if on that day when my umbilical cord was cut, my throat had been cut instead,

translation.text: I would not have fallen into so many troubles, or undergone so many hardships. ||76||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, answer evil with goodness; do not fill your mind with anger.

transliteration.text: pharīdā burē dā bhalā kar gusā man n hadhāi .

translation.text: Fareed, only those good deeds done in the world will be of any use in the Court of the Lord. ||100||

transliteration.text: pharīdā amal j kītē dunī vich daragah āē kanm .100.

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

translation.text: They peck at the roots and live on the ground, but they do not leave the Lord's side. ||101||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the seasons change, the woods shake and the leaves drop from the trees.

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: Why do you tear apart your fine clothes, and take to wearing a rough blanket?

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਘਰ ਹੀ ਬੈਠਿਆ ਸਹੁ ਮਿਲੈ ਜੇ ਨੀਅਤਿ ਰਾਸਿ ਕਰੇਇ ॥੧੦੪॥
section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: O Nanak, even sitting in your own home, you can meet the Lord, if your mind is in the right place. ||104||

transliteration.text: nānak ghar hī baithiā sah milai jē nīat rās karēi .104.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the world dances as it dances, and you dance with it as well.

transliteration.text: pharīdā dunī vajāī vajadī tūn bhī vajah nāl .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Sheikh Farid
author.description:
Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਸੋਈ ਜੀਉ ਨ ਵਜਦਾ ਜਿਸੁ ਅਲਹੁ ਕਰਦਾ ਸਾਰ ॥੧੧੦॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: That soul alone does not dance with it, who is under the care of the Lord God. ||110||

transliteration.text: sōī jīu n vajadā jis alah karadā sār .110.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

translation.text: Fifth Mehl:

transliteration.text: mah 5 .

text: ਫਰੀਦਾ ਦਿਲੁ ਰਤਾ ਇਸੁ ਦੁਨੀ ਸਿਉ ਦੁਨੀ ਨ ਕਿਤੈ ਕੰਮਿ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Fareed, the heart is imbued with this world, but the world is of no use to it at all.

transliteration.text: pharīdā dil ratā is dunī siu dunī n kitai kanm .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: It is so difficult to be like the fakeers - the Holy Saints; it is only achieved by perfect karma. ||111||

transliteration.text: misal phakīrānh gākharī s pāīai pūr karanm .111.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The first watch of the night brings flowers, and the later watches of the night bring fruit.

transliteration.text: pahilai paharai phularā phal bhī pashā rāt .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Those who remain awake and aware, receive the gifts from the Lord. ||112||

transliteration.text: jō jāgannh lahann sē sāī kannō dāt .112.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The gifts are from our Lord and Master; who can force Him to bestow them?

transliteration.text: dātī sāhib sandīā kiā chalai tis nāl .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Some are awake, and do not receive them, while He awakens others from sleep to bless them. ||113||

transliteration.text: ik jāgandē nā lahanh ikanhā sutiā dēi uthāl .113.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: You search for your Husband Lord; you must have some fault in your body.

transliteration.text: dhūdhēdīē suhāg kū tau tan kāī kōr .

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Those who are known as happy soul-brides, do not look to others. ||114||

translation.text: Within yourself, make patience the bow, and make patience the bowstring.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Make patience the arrow, the Creator will not let you miss the target. ||115||

translation.text: Those who are patient abide in patience; in this way, they burn their bodies.

translation.text: They are close to the Lord, but they do not reveal their secret to anyone. ||116||

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Let patience be your purpose in life; implant this within your being.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: In this way, you will grow into a great river; you will not break off into a tiny stream. ||117||

translation.text: Fareed, it is difficult to be a dervish - a Holy Saint; it is easier to love bread when it is buttered.

section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: My body is cooking like an oven; my bones are burning like firewood.

Saint Sheikh Farid [? - 1552], also known as Baba Farid, Sheikh Brahm or Farid Sani, was the tenth successor to the famous Fariduddin Shakarganj [1173 - 1266], a Muslim Sufi of the Chishti Sufi order who was the first major poet of the Punjabi language.

Saint Sheikh Farid met Guru Nanak Dev in Pakpattan, where a disciple of the Sheikh had overheard Guru Nanak, along with his two disciples Bhai Bala and Mardana, singing hymns about God. The disciple went to his master, Saint Sheikh Farid, and at once upon hearing the hymn from his disciple he set off to meet Guru Nanak himself, which gave him the peace and joy he was looking for.

text: ਹਿਆਉ ਨ ਕੈਹੀ ਠਾਹਿ ਮਾਣਕ ਸਭ ਅਮੋਲਵੇ ॥੧੨੯॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: Do not break anyone's heart; these are all priceless jewels. ||129||

transliteration.text: hiāu n kaihī thāh mānak sabh amōlavē .129.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਸਭਨਾ ਮਨ ਮਾਣਿਕ ਠਾਹਣੁ ਮੂਲਿ ਮਚਾਂਗਵਾ ॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: The minds of all are like precious jewels; to harm them is not good at all.

transliteration.text: sabhanā man mānik thāhan mūl machānhgavā .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਜੇ ਤਉ ਪਿਰੀਆ ਦੀ ਸਿਕ ਹਿਆਉ ਨ ਠਾਹੇ ਕਹੀ ਦਾ ॥੧੩੦॥
section: Salok Sheikh Farid (Verses Of Saint Sheikh Farid)

translation.text: If you desire your Beloved, then do not break anyone's heart. ||130||

transliteration.text: jē tau pirīā dī sik hiāu n thāhē kahī dā .130.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
